sub_topic: Finding the derivative of a trigonometric function
message_1: Find the derivative of y = 3sin(5x) - 2cos(3x) at x = π/6.
message_2:
To find the derivative of y = 3sin(5x) - 2cos(3x) with respect to x, we will use the chain rule.

The derivative of sin(ax) is acos(ax) * a, and the derivative of cos(ax) is -asin(ax) * a.

So, the derivative of y with respect to x is:

dy/dx = d(3sin(5x))/dx - d(2cos(3x))/dx
dy/dx = 3 * 5cos(5x) - 2 * (-3)sin(3x)
dy/dx = 15cos(5x) + 6sin(3x)

Now, we will evaluate the derivative at x = π/6:

dy/dx(π/6) = 15cos(5(π/6)) + 6sin(3(π/6))
dy/dx(π/6) = 15cos(5π/6) + 6sin(3π/6)
dy/dx(π/6) = 15cos(5π/6) + 6sin(π/2)

Now, we will use the trigonometric values of cos(5π/6) and sin(π/2):

cos(5π/6) = -√3/2
sin(π/2) = 1

So, dy/dx(π/6) = 15(-√3/2) + 6(1)
dy/dx(π/6) = -15√3/2 + 6

Thus, the derivative of y = 3sin(5x) - 2cos(3x) at x = π/6 is -15√3/2 + 6.
